name: Great Dane
description: Great Danes are gentle giants with significant health concerns due to their massive size. Bloat is life-threatening and common in this breed. Their short lifespan and high risk of serious conditions make pet insurance essential for Great Dane owners.

healthRisks.notes: Leading cause of death in Great Danes
Heart disease common in giant breeds
Giant breeds have elevated cancer risk

faqs.question: Why is Great Dane insurance so expensive?
faqs.answer: Great Danes have extremely high rates of serious conditions—bloat, heart disease, cancer, and joint problems. Their large size also means higher surgery costs. Insurance reflects these elevated risks.

faqs.question: What is bloat and why is it dangerous?
faqs.answer: Bloat (Gastric Dilatation-Volvulus) is when the stomach fills with gas and twists. It's fatal within hours without surgery. Great Danes have the highest bloat rate of any breed—insurance is essential.

faqs.question: Is pet insurance worth it for a Great Dane?
faqs.answer: Absolutely essential. The question isn't if your Great Dane will have major medical expenses, but when. Bloat surgery alone is $7,500+, and most Danes face multiple serious health issues.

faqs.question: Should I consider a prophylactic gastropexy?
faqs.answer: A gastropexy (stomach tacking) can prevent bloat and is often done during spay/neuter. It costs $200-500 when combined with another surgery. Some insurance plans cover this preventive procedure.

faqs.question: What annual limit do I need for a Great Dane?
faqs.answer: We recommend unlimited coverage or at least $20,000+ annually. A single bloat surgery plus heart disease treatment could easily exceed $15,000 in one year.
